repnme.cdata!:
Guinea-Bissau - Coastal and Biodiversity
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Coastal and Biodiversity
            Management Project for Guinea-Bissau were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory; Global environmental
            objective (GEO) outcomes were also moderately satisfactory;
            risk to development outcome was moderate; risk to GEO
            outcome was also moderate; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory; and borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: the
            sustainability of projects in countries like Guinea-Bissau
            benefits from multiple, donor-supported interventions over a
            lengthy period. A series of follow-up projects can be the
            most important means for securing sustainability, and since
            organizational and institutional capacity is generally
            modest and the problems immense, multiple projects which
            address 'segments' of large, complex sectors such
            as sustainable land management, environment and
            biodiversity, may also be the best course as reflected in
            new, related operations Stability of the Bank and borrower
            core teams is advantageous, albeit not easy to achieve. Such
            stability can have major advantages over time especially for
            technically difficult projects in troubled environments.
            Intense and sustained supervision is entirely appropriate
            for high-risk environments like Guinea-Bissau but does not
            need to be costly or always direct, face-to-face encounters
            with country counterparts. The Cufada Park experience was a
            milestone in the Bank's relationship with the
            Government, showing how the Bank can support the
            country's natural resource management agenda. Poor
            procurement performance is a serious constraint for projects
            in Guinea-Bissau due to the lack of in-country capacity.
            Mentoring arrangements need a formal structure with
            guidelines on responsibilities and expected outcomes.
            Building capacity and empowering community beneficiaries
            through continuous 'learning by doing' which
            extends well beyond the specific micro-project cycle is
            prudent and innovative.

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea-Bissau - Biodiversity Conservation
            Project : environmental and social management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Biodiversity
            Conservation Project is to support the country to strengthen
            Institute for Biodiversity and Protected Areas (IBAP's)
            management of Guinea-Bissau's existing five national
            parks, and pilot the establishment and operation of a
            mechanism to sustainably finance at least two of these
            parks. Negative impacts includes: notification and worker
            safety, air quality, noise, water quality, waste management,
            medical waste, and direct or indirect hazards to public
            traffic and pedestrians by construction activities.
            Mitigation measures includes: 1) the contractor formally
            agrees that all work will be carried out in a safe and
            disciplined manner designed to minimize impacts on
            neighboring residents and environment; 2) the surrounding
            environment shall be kept free of debris to minimize dust,
            there will be no open burning of construction / waste
            material at the site; 3) construction noise will be limited
            to restricted times agreed to in the permit; 4) the site
            will establish appropriate erosion and sediment control
            measures; 5) waste collection and disposal pathways and
            sites will be identified for all major waste types expected
            from demolition and construction activities; 6) appropriate
            storage facilities for medical waste are in place; and 7)
            traffic management system and staff training, especially for
            site access and near-site heavy traffic.

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea-Bissau - Coastal and Biodiversity
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project aims to build the capacity
            Government agencies and natural resource users in
            Guinea-Bissau to collaboratively manage coastal environments
            and biodiversity for both conservation and sustainable
            development ends. Towards this objective, the project
            comprises three inter-related components plus one component
            for project management. There are four project components.
            Component 1 will both strengthen the institutional framework
            and management capacity for biodiversity and protected
            areas. Component 2 promotes sustainable use of biological
            resources at the local level and includes two main groups of
            activities: (1) It provides a grant funding mechanism (Fund
            for Local Environmental Initiatives - FIAL) to promote
            sustainable use activities inside and outside of the
            targeted protected areas, and (2) Builds the capacity to
            strengthen the management, monitoring, control and
            surveillance of reserved fishing zones and fisheries.
            Component 3 establish and implement an environmental and
            social safeguards framework. Component 4 finances project
            management and monitoring and evaluation.

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea Bissau - Coastal and Biodiversity
            Management Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Coastal and Biodiversity Management
            Project will facilitate responsible management of natural
            resource management in, and around five protected areas, and
            in three reserved fishing zones in Guinea-Bissau, while
            assisting the country in setting up a process of
            environmental, and social screening of development projects.
            It is foreseen that land acquisition, and thus resettlement,
            will occur as a result of project implementation, and this
            policy framework sets the guidelines to avoid as possible,
            or minimize adverse impacts on local populations, and,
            provides compensation as follows. Land losses will be
            compensated at replacement costs, while housing and any
            physical structure will be replaced, in which case
            construction materials and assistance will be provided as
            needed. It is important to note, that house gardens,
            agricultural fields, grazing lands, and other common areas
            lost will be replaced with plots of equal size and
            productive potential, to include as well infrastructure,
            such as access to water and transport availability.
            Continued access to natural resources in the core areas may
            be permitted under specific conditions, but alternate access
            will be provided in the resettlement area. Resettlement
            sites will be provided basic social infrastructure, such as
            village wells, communal stores, schools, clinics, and
            electricity. Farmers particularly affected by annual, or
            perennial crop, and rice losses will be allowed harvesting,
            and, will later be provided with alternative plots of equal
            size, soil fertility, and productive capacity for
            agricultural purposes. Improved seeds, and technical
            assistance on processing techniques will be provided.
            Similarly, assistance in fisheries development will be
            provided through improved technologies, and processing techniques.

            Subsistence livelihoods, sustainable development,
            sustainable exploitation, sustainable management,
            sustainable use

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea-Bissau - Coastal and Biodiversity
            Management Project : environmental and social impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Coastal and Biodiversity Management Project, which
            facilitate responsible management of natural resource
            management in and around five protected areas and in three
            reserved fishing zones in Guinea-Bissau, and assists the
            country in setting up a process of environmental and social
            screening of development projects in the country. This
            report focuses on air pollution management, biodiversity
            conservation, fishing reserves conservation, and protected
            areas management: Formulate a regulatory and legislative
            framework for natural resource management, including
            regulating barracuda fishing, incorporating traditional
            practices and employing participatory practices. Prepare
            alternative protected area management plans for the national
            parks, with special attention to identifying elephant forest
            habitats; establish a legal framework for protected areas
            management, and promote disseminate  about this information.
            To protect endangered species, conduct inventories and
            undertake studies to determine the status of the most
            endangered species-particularly those of the sea turtle, the
            shark, the manatee, and the hippopotamus-and study the
            connection between these species and the indigenous
            populations; and harmonize research activities with those of
            the Global Environmental Facility (GEF), research centers,
            universities, and nongovernmental organizations. Also,
            conduct studies to determine the socioeconomic impacts on
            identified populations of protecting the species mentioned
            above. To promote biodiversity conservation, evaluate
            traditional practices in order to integrated them into the
            conservation program; and encourage the participation of the
            local population and develops a program to inform, educate,
            and train them.
